thread.title: Singaporeans from all walks of life send online wishes and encouragement to PSLE pupils
thread.title_full: Singaporeans from all walks of life send online wishes and encouragement to PSLE pupils

posts.title: Singaporeans from all walks of life send online wishes and encouragement to PSLE pupils
posts.text:
Singaporeans from all walks of life send online wishes and encouragement to PSLE pupils The McDonald's Instagram post promoting love on PSLE results day. PHOTO: MCDONALD'S/ INSTAGRAM Published Derek Wong 
SINGAPORE - While 38,808 pupils received their Primary School Leaving Examination (PSLE) results on Thursday (Nov 24), it seemed like the entire country was getting the results together with the children, as Singapore celebrated its best PSLE performance ever. 
About 98.4 per cent of pupils who took this year's PSLE are able to go on to a secondary school. 
Prominent personalities, organisations and brands in Singapore have offered their well-wishes and encouragement to the young ones. 
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong posted his congratulations to the pupils with a message of encouragement. 
"I hope you will take the next few years in secondary school to discover and nurture your talents and interests, and develop a passion for lifelong learning. It will serve you well as you journey through life's stages," he said. 
Other politicians also offered their well-wishes and advice. 
Minister for Social and Family Development Tan Chuan-Jin had a message for parents. He encouraged them to "Please Support, Love and Encourage them always" as one day "we (parents) will need their support, love and encouragement too". 
Senior Minister of State Josephine Teo posted a picture of Star Wars character Darth Vader giving the thumbs-up, telling pupils that "there's no need to be stressed, as long as you've done your best!" 
Nominated MP Kuik Shiao-yin published a heartfelt note "You Are More Than One Result" on her Facebook. She had a clear message to the pupils: "You are and always will be so much more than one result." 
Corporations and movements also sent out messages for the pupils. 
The Singapore Kindness Movement posted a note from a St Anthony's Canossian Primary School teacher, Ms Teoh, to her Primary 6 class, with the words "Success is not final, failure is not fatal: it is the courage to continue that counts." 
Meanwhile, fast food chain McDonald's put up a picture of beverages resembling parents and a child, with the message "No matter what, keep sharing the love!"

thread.section_title: Student, 18, knocked out in Salford McDonald’s because she’s from London – Metro
thread.title: Student, 18, knocked out in Salford McDonald’s because she’s from London
thread.title_full: Student, 18, knocked out in Salford McDonald’s because she’s from London

posts.author: Jimmy Nsubuga
posts.title: Student, 18, knocked out in Salford McDonald’s because she’s from London
posts.text:
Megan Westlotorn, 18, after the attack in McDonald’s (Picture: MEN) A man knocked a student unconscious in McDonald’s after he discovered she was from London. 
Shocking images showed Megan Westlotorn, 18, in blood-stained clothes following the attack near Salford Crescent, Greater Manchester, last Sunday.
She had been waiting at the tills to collect her order at around 3am when she was approached by the suspect.
MORE: How to live forever*, according to a Japanese longevity chef 
Megan Westlotorn has warned other students to be vigilant (Picture: MEN) ‘I noticed him talking to people when I went up to get my chicken nuggets,’ the Salford University student said.
‘As soon as he asked where I was from and I said I was from London, he just switched.
‘He started swearing at me and giving me abuse. He called me a f*g Southerner, saying I was f*g tramps and that he hated Londoners.’
The man then punched her in the face as she walked over to the disabled toilets.
MORE: Murder probe as boy, 5, dies after being badly injured in park 
Ms Westlotorn, a first year student, added: ‘The next thing I knew, I was on the floor in a pool of blood.
‘I was just really shocked. I didn’t know what had happened. I didn’t expect to get punched in the face like that.’
The south Londoner is now advising other students to remain vigilant following the attack.
Greater Manchester Police are investigating the incident.
The suspect was described as white, around 5ft 4ins, with a Salford accent.
Anyone with information should call police on 101, quoting incident number 376 of 20/11/16, or Crimestoppers, anonymously, on 0800 555 111. 
MORE: Tsunami warning after massive earthquake strikes near El Salvador

CHICAGO — WGN’s Lourdes Duarte and Dan Ponce hosted the annual “McDonald’s Thanksgiving Parade” on Thursday, November 24, live on Chicago’s Very Own WGN-TV, nationally on the WGN America cable network and worldwide on WGNTV.com. 
Chicago’s 83rd annual holiday parade kicked off the 2016 holiday season on historic State Street with high-stepping equestrians, fabulous floats, actor/comedian Matt Walsh as grand marshal, singer Craig Campbell, comedian Sebastian Maniscalo, chef Graham Elliot, actor Yuri Sardarov, actor Dante Brown, actress Emma Kenney, the Harlem Globetrotters and Santa Claus. WGN goodwill ambassador and Chicago favorite, Bozo, presided over the WGN-TV float along with Tom Skilling, Dean Richards, Cortney Hall, Nancy Loo, Sean Lewis and Paul Lisnek. 
Performances included Musicality, Laura Bretan, Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey’s “Out of This World,” Broadway in Chicago’s “Finding Neverland,” Apollo Chorus of Chicago, Ayodele Drum & Dance, Ballet Folklorico Sones Mexicanos, Jackie Taylor’s “The Other Cinderella,” Chicago Korean Dance Company, Chicago Multi-Cultural Dance Center’s Hiplet Ballerinas, Hromovytsia Ukrainian Dance Ensemble of Chicago, Lucid Dance Company, Nancy Chippendale’s American Tap Company, and Tsukasa Taiko. 
WGN first televised the parade in 1966 when it was called the “State Street Christmas Parade.”

thread.title: Woman attacked in Salford after man discovered she is from London | Granada
thread.title_full: Woman attacked in Salford after man discovered she is from London | Granada - ITV News

posts.author: itv.com
posts.title: Woman attacked in Salford after man discovered she is from London | Granada
posts.text:
Police are appealing after a student was viciously attacked in a McDonald’s branch in Salford after a man discovered she was from London.
Megan Westlotorn, 18, was with friends in the McDonald’s near Salford Crescent when she was knocked unconscious.
Megan Westlotorn (left) before she was attacked Credit: MEN Syndication Police are now investigating the unprovoked attack on the sports science student on Sunday morning. Megan, who is in her first year at university, was waiting at the tills to collect her order, when a man started speaking to her.
She says it was only when he asked her where she was from that his demeanor suddenly changed - and he lashed out.
The sports science student, who has shared pictures of her blood-stained clothes after the incident, said: “I noticed him talking to people when I went up to get my chicken nuggets.
“As soon as he asked where I was from and I said I was from London, he just switched.
“He started swearing at me and giving me abuse. He called me a f g Southerner, saying I was f g tramps and that he hated Londoners.
I stepped back and told him I was backing off from the situation.”
When Megan walked away she thought her ordeal was over.
But when she went over towards disabled toilet, the man went over to her and punched in her in the face.
“The next thing I knew, I was on the floor in a pool of blood,”
“He must have knocked me unconscious for a minute or so. There was blood pouring from my nose.
“I was just really shocked. I didn’t know what had happened. I didn’t expect to get punched in the face like that.
“When I found my friend she couldn’t believe what had happened either. It all happened so quickly.”
– Megan Westlotorn The McDonald's branch near Salford Crescent Credit: Google Maps Megan, who has only just moved away from her home in South East London to start her degree, is urging other students to be aware of her attacker. “I just want other people to be vigilant and watch out for him,” she added.
Megan described her attacker as white, around 5ft 4ins, with a Salford accent.
Greater Manchester Police confirmed they are investigating the incident.
Last updated Fri 25 Nov 2016 Salford

thread.title: Huh, so *this* is what eating 10,000 calories worth of McDonald’s looks like
thread.title_full: Huh, so *this* is what eating 10,000 calories worth of McDonald’s looks like

posts.title: Huh, so *this* is what eating 10,000 calories worth of McDonald’s looks like
posts.text: Huh, so *this* is what eating 10,000 calories worth of McDonald’s looks like Ashley Rey More We just got a peak at what eating 10,000 calories of McDonald’s looks like, and we’re amazed. Super-eater (yep… there’s a such thing ) and YouTube sensation Yuka Kinoshita laid all of our overeating guilt trips to rest with her latest video. So, good ahead and grab those seconds, thirds and fourths without shame, guys! The tiny woman elegantly scarfed down her weight’s worth of Japanese Micky D’s treats, including: five Big Macs, ten dark chocolate pies, ten white chocolate pies, three tiramisu McFlurries, three large fries and three large cokes! And, spoiler alert, she totally lived to tell the tale. Watch Yuka devour he McDonald’s treats in the viral video, below! Mind. Blown. We have to admit, our stomachs totally hurt after watching Yuka in action. The real question is…how in the hell did she make room for everything?! On the other hand, Japanese McDonald’s food looks a lot…well, lighter than that of the American menu. We can almost bet that we wouldn’t have to eat half of what she sate to meet the 10,000 calorie quota. But hey, we’ll take any guilt-free reassurance we can get when it comes to stuffing our faces this season. Dig those stretchy jeans up out the back of your closets, because you’ll definitely need them!

thread.title: McDonald’s to deploy mobile ordering in 2017
thread.title_full: McDonald’s to deploy mobile ordering in 2017

posts.author: Danny Zepeda
posts.title: McDonald’s to deploy mobile ordering in 2017
posts.text:
It will soon be easier to order a Big Mac than ever. McDonald’s will introduce mobile ordering in 10 major markets starting next year. The move is the latest step by the burger giant to embrace technology throughout its stores in the United States.
Mobile ordering is a practice many businesses are starting to implement in their stores to boost sales. Starbucks introduced its version of it last year through its popular mobile app, allowing customers to order their favorite drinks before arriving at the store, making the experience of picking up coffee much quicker. Dunkin’ Donuts followed suit.
There’s no word yet on how McDonald’s will implement its version of mobile ordering, however.
McDonald’s already began to update stores around the country, adding virtual menus and self-serving kiosks. It has gone through some tough times lately with the rise of awareness in healthy eating that juxtaposed terribly with its reputation of unhealthy fast-food. As the company tries to become a “modern, progressive company,” as one of its executive noted on Thursday, this is just the latest step to attract customers.
Businesses aim to adapt with technology We’ve begun to assume that we can order anything from our phones and receive it at our doorsteps, without ever leaving home, thanks to products like Amazon Prime Now. As a result, companies like McDonald’s are also beginning to adopt this type of customer service. It’s a good idea, no doubt, but we’re not quite sure how it fits into McDonald’s vision of creating a healthier customer base.


Source : Reuters

thread.title: McDonald’s caught engaging in propaganda scheme at high schools, teaching that ‘fast food is nutritious’
thread.title_full: McDonald’s caught engaging in propaganda scheme at high schools, teaching that ‘fast food is nutritious’

posts.author: IWB
posts.title: McDonald’s caught engaging in propaganda scheme at high schools, teaching that ‘fast food is nutritious’
posts.text:
November 25, 2016 
by: J. D. Heyes 
( NaturalNews ) Do you think it’s really possible to actually lose weight eating nothing but a steady diet of pre-processed McDonald’s fast food ? Well, the restaurant chain would sure like for you to believe that, even though most items on McDonald’s menus have been proven to be stuffed with unhealthy ingredients. 
Nevertheless, the chain wants to convince people that its food offerings contain the daily recommended allowances of carbohydrates, sugar, protein and fat – and as such, it is completely healthy to eat whatever is on the menu, because none of it causes obesity or the many ailments associated with it, as has been claimed. 
Do you remember when John Cisna, an Iowa high school teacher, claimed to have lost 56 pounds eating nothing but food from McDonald’s in 2013? He even wrote a book about it, called My McDonald’s Diet . Mindless nutritional propaganda 
Cisna claims that he limited his daily intake to 2,000 calories and exercised for 45 minutes, five times per week. After that he said he lost a total of 21 inches off his chest, waist and hips; his total cholesterol fell from 249 to 190; his body mass index (BMI) fell from 38 to 30; and he dropped to 224 pounds from 280 pounds, Anon HQ reports . 
In a documentary that McDonald’s is peddling to high schools everywhere as a tool for healthy eating, Cisna says, “I ate 540 straight meals at McDonald’s. I spent a half a year of my life eating nothing but McDonald’s and I know it works so when I hear the skeptics, it doesn’t disgruntle me. It actually fires me up because those are the people that I have to educate.” 
Ever since, as a paid brand ambassador for the fast food chain, he has crisscrossed the U.S., promoting McDonald’s fare to middle- and high school students. He has even talked to students studying dietetics. 
In his own documentary, Cisna attempts to discredit the hit film , Supersize Me , which laid bare the kind of damage to your health that only eating fast food – especially in large portions – can do. 
But in the end, most legitimate dietitians and health experts were not impressed with his “findings.” In fact, most of them pointed to some very obvious factors that led to his weight loss – and it wasn’t typical McDonald’s food that did it. 
In an interview with Today , registered dietitian nutritionist Elisa Zied of New York City, author of the book, Younger Next Week , lauded Cisna’s success at losing weight, but said that his recommendation of a strictly McDonald’s-only diet was not realistic. ‘I wouldn’t recommend this to anyone’ 
That’s because much of his weight-loss results came from cutting his daily caloric intake and by exercising. Plus, she said, it is very likely that while he lost weight and cut his cholesterol level, his diet was probably high in sodium, low in fiber and consisted of far fewer vitamins and minerals found in healthier diets that include fruits, vegetables , whole grains and other foods rich in nutrients. 
“I personally would not recommend this to anyone,” she said . “Fast food can be part of a healthful, balanced and nutrient-rich diet but it…shouldn’t be a large part.” 
Actually, it should play no part in your diet. 
Zied advises people to prepare most of their own food fresh at home while eating out less. 
As an update, The Washington Post reported that McDonald’s has quietly ended it’s controversial program involving sending Cisna to schools to talk about its food and nutrition in the same breath. 
Critics lambasted the effort as an underhanded way for the fast food chain to legitimize fast food as a nutrition alternative to kids who would grow up thinking that burgers, fries and shakes are actually good for you.

posts.author: Daniel Trujillo
posts.title: Rio Rancho McDonald’s hands out Thanksgiving meals
posts.text:
RIO RANCHO, N.M. (KRQE) – A McDonald’s in Rio Rancho opened its doors to anyone who wanted a Thanksgiving meal.
For the 22nd year McDonalds and St. Felix Pantry teamed up to serve meals to anyone who came in for one. Some who showed up to eat said it was a time to be around some friendly people to spread the love of the Thanksgiving holiday.
Along the serving line were the Rio Rancho Police Chief and the Rio Rancho Mayor who say it’s an honor to be there.
“There’s so many people that volunteer their time here and you know as mayor to join this is absolutely wonderful,” said Rio Rancho Mayor Greg Hull.
They expected to serve more than 700 people Thursday.

posts.author: CBS North Carolina
posts.title: Man shoots his way into NC McDonald’s, robs it
posts.text:
FOREST CITY, N.C. (WSPA) – A McDonald’s in Forest City was robbed at gunpoint after a man fired his gun into the building’s glass to get into the restaurant.
According to Forest City police, the suspect approached an employee in the parking lot of the McDonald’s on Wells Drive and tried to force his way into the restaurant around 4:40 a.m. Friday.
Police say the employee was able to make it inside and lock the door before the suspect fired his weapon into the glass and made his way inside where he demanded money at gunpoint.
The suspect was described as a black man 5 feet 10 inches to 6 feet tall wearing a dark colored hoodie, dark colored pants, and dark colored boots.
Anyone with information is asked to call the Rutherford County Central Communications Center at (828) 286-2911 or Crime Stoppers at (828) 286-TIPS.

posts.title: McDonald’s introducing Grand Mac, Mac Jr.
posts.text:
McDonald’s introducing Grand Mac, Mac Jr. Grand Mac made with 1/3-pound of beef Published On: Nov 25 2016 11:56:53 AM CST Justin Sullivan/Getty Images 
The signature hamburger at McDonald's is getting company.The fast food franchise is adding two new burgers inspired by the Big Mac to its line-up next year.The Grand Mac is made with 1/3-pound of beef. The Mac Jr. is a single-layer burger.The Grand Mac is what you'd get if you upsized the Big Mac, and the Mac Jr. is what you’d get if you shrunk it.All three will still have all-beef patties, special sauce, Lettuce, cheese, pickles and onions on a sesame seed bun.The Grand Mac and the Mac Jr. will be sold for a limited time on in early 2017. thread.title: McDonald's will introduce mobile payment and ordering in the US in the first half of 2017
thread.title_full: McDonald's will introduce mobile payment and ordering in the US in the first half of 2017

posts.title: McDonald's will introduce mobile payment and ordering in the US in the first half of 2017
posts.text: › McDonald's will introduce mobile payment and ordering in the US in the first half of 2017 McDonald's will introduce mobile payment and ordering in the US in the first half of 2017 Posted: Tags : Apps - Apps + Our phones are incredibly powerful tools that can be used for a whole plethora of things. They can track our steps, access the entire Internet, allow us to immediately connect with friends and family, capture photos and videos, and so much more. However, something they currently can't do is order Big Macs. McDonald's is one of the most popular fast-food chains in the world, but despite their popularity, the company has been a bit lacking when it comes to their adoption of new technology. Companies such as Starbucks allow customers to place orders for food and drinks directly through the official Starbucks app, and it looks like McDonald's will be introducing similar functionality within their own app next year. Starting sometime in the first half of 2017, McDonald's will introduce the ability to order items off of their menu through the McDonald's app on your smartphone, followed by a full-fledged national rollout in the second half of the year. The app will allow you to both order and pay for your items within the app, and although this isn't anything we haven't seen before from McDonald's' competitors, it's nice to see that the company is finally taking the right steps forward to being more mobile-friendly. One of the biggest draws for fast-food chains, such as McDonald's, is the ability to get a drink or bite to eat as quickly as possible. This factor can be easily diminished by a long line in-store or a backed-up drive-thru, and the addition of mobile ordering and paying should help to drastically decrease the amount of time it takes for you to get your food upon visiting McDonald's. McDonald's has to to announce exact details on how their rollout of mobile ordering will take place next year, but we should get specifics as we draw closer to the second half of 2017.

DETROIT (AP) — McDonald's restaurant owners are donating 1,000 live Christmas trees to Detroit-area families.
Five hundred trees, tree stands and gift cards will be given at a private event Saturday morning to families pre-selected by area churches.
The remaining trees will be available from 1-3 p.m. on a first-come basis at the McDonald's on Eight Mile Road near Woodward Avenue.
The trees are 5 feet tall to 6 feet tall.
Event organizers say Detroit-area McDonald's restaurant owners also have donated turkeys, hats and scarfs, school supplies and other items to families in need as part of their support for the community.

thread.title_full: McDonald’s introducing Grand Mac and Mac Jr.

posts.author: CNN Wire
posts.title: McDonald’s introducing Grand Mac and Mac Jr.
posts.text:
McDonald’s signature hamburger is getting company.
The fast food franchise is adding two new burgers inspired by the Big Mac to its line-up next year.
The Grand Mac is made with one-third pound of beef while the Mac Jr. is a single-layer burger.
You could say the Grand Mac is what you’d get if you up-sized the Big Mac and the Mac Jr. is what you would get if you shrunk it.
All three will still have all-beef patties, special sauce, lettuce, cheese, pickles and onions on a Sesame seed bun.
The Grand Mac and the Mac Jr. will be sold for a limited time on McDonald’s national menu in early 2017.

thread.title: Canadiens forwards rib fans about McDonald's burgers | NHL.com
thread.title_full: Canadiens forwards rib fans about McDonald's burgers | NHL.com

posts.title: Canadiens forwards rib fans about McDonald's burgers | NHL.com
posts.text:
Canadiens forwards rib fans about McDonald's burgers Brendan Gallagher, Alex Galchenyuk surprise patrons choosing between their burgers NHL.com @NHL 
Alex Galchenyuk and Brendan Gallagher may be Montreal Canadiens teammates but they remain rival burger chefs. 
Just prior to the start of the 2016 NHL season, both players created their own signature burgers at McDonald's self-serve kiosks. But the question remained: Which one is better? 
Watch: Canadiens forwards engage in battle of burgers 
Customers at a Montreal McDonald's were asked to pick between the two burgers and had a little surprise waiting for them. After they made their choice, one of the two players would gave them an earful via video screen. 
"You just made one of the biggest mistakes of your life," Galchenyuk said after a patron picked Gallagher's burger. 
"You made him really sad, which makes me really happy," Gallagher said to another customer who chose his creation. 
Galchenyuk's brief foray into French is also a pretty funny moment in the ad. 
So who did the restaurant-goers prefer as their chef? There was some debate about that too. Galchenyuk said that the score was 5-5, but Gallagher said it was 5-4, his lead.

posts.text:
Click to share on Pinterest (Opens in new window) Google maps image of the McDonald's in Forest City. 
FOREST CITY, N.C. (WSPA) – A McDonald’s in Rutherford County was robbed at gunpoint after a man fired his gun into the building’s glass to get into the restaurant. 
According to Forest City police, the suspect approached an employee in the parking lot of the McDonald’s on Wells Drive and tried to force his way into the restaurant around 4:40 a.m. Friday. 
Police say the employee was able to make it inside and lock the door before the suspect fired his weapon into the glass and made his way inside. 
Once in the restaurant, the man he demanded money at gunpoint. 
The suspect was described as a black man 5 feet 10 inches to 6 feet tall wearing a dark colored hoodie, dark colored pants, and dark colored boots. 
Anyone with information is asked to call the Rutherford County Central Communications Center at (828) 286-2911 or Crime Stoppers at (828) 286-TIPS. Share this:

thread.title: Thumbs up to McDonald's grad
thread.title_full: Thumbs up to McDonald's grad

posts.title: Thumbs up to McDonald's grad
posts.text:
Thumbs up to McDonald's grad Saturday Nov 26, 2016 at 2:01 AM 
Thumbs up to Josh Dunne, a 19-year-old in Kittery, Maine, who deserves enormous credit for taking full advantage of the McDonald's restaurant chain's program to earn a high school diploma. 
We reported on Dunne's heartwarming story earlier this week. Dunne had dropped out of Traip Academy as a junior after problems at home and struggles with academics. His parents weren't getting along, and his mother, by her own admission, was drinking way too much. “He was watching his mom self-destruct,” Linda Dunne said this week. 
Josh Dunne, who worked for three years without a car, often walking 30 minutes, has earned his diploma ahead of schedule while working 50 hours a week. He also bought a car recently and earned promotions at work, recently becoming assistant manager. His mom couldn't be more proud and said she's been sober for a year. 
Credit goes to Dunne, of course, but also to McDonald's Archways to Opportunity program, which offers free education to its employees through the accredited Career Online High School. Dunne was nurtured and encouraged by the Kittery McDonald's leaders, including co-owners Peter Napoli and Sal Napoli, and store manager Alex Landry. 
Dunne's story was a big hit on Seacoastonline.com, and he got many congratulations on the Seacoastonline Facebook page. Dunne joined the conversation, too, posting a comment on our Facebook page that shows he's aware his accomplishment is bigger than himself. 
"Thank you everybody for your support, encouragement, and congratulations," Dunne wrote. "I appreciate it and it means everything to me. To some McDonald's might just seem like a part time, dead end job, but I want to tell everyone personally that there are so many opportunities to take advantage of. There's so much to learn not just from the company itself, but also the employees, and especially the guests. If you didn't obtain your diploma or know somebody that didn't, then I encourage you with all my heart to join McDonald's, rise through the ranks, seize the opportunities, and earn your diploma. Please share this article so more people can become educated about the great opportunities that are available to them." 
**** 
Thumbs up to everyone who donated their time on Thanksgiving day. This includes those involved with hosting the Portsmouth Rotary Club's 45th annual community dinner at the St. Nicholas Greek Church. 
Numerous Rotarians and volunteers helped deliver, prepare and serve food. They cooked 26 turkeys and baked 60 pies. Donations of food came from Portsmouth Regional Hospital, baked goods were provided by Me & Ollies and flowers for the tables were donated by Flower Kiosk. This dinner is appreciated by many who attend. 
**** 
Thumbs up to 7-year-old second-grader Georgia Merrill and her parents for starting the Georgia Peach Project to raise money to help feed people in need. 
More than $1,000 has been raised so far for the New Hampshire Food Bank. The effort started when Georgia saw a man on the street holding a sign saying "I'm hungry." 
Georgia told her mom, Erin, about it, and they worked together to set up a website, share it on Facebook and recruit donations. Her mom said she's always looking for volunteer opportunities for her kids, and that's great to see. Parents teaching their kids the value of giving back at a young age is great for our communities. 
Donations can be made to Georgia's cause at http://bit.ly/2fPgL0p. About Us

thread.section_title: You’ll soon be able to get McDonald’s coffee on flights – Metro
thread.title: You’ll soon be able to get McDonald’s coffee on flights
thread.title_full: You’ll soon be able to get McDonald’s coffee on flights

posts.author: Ellen Scott
posts.title: You’ll soon be able to get McDonald’s coffee on flights
posts.text:
(Picture: McDonald’s/metro.co.uk) We’re one step closer to our dreams of having McDonald’s shakes on a plane.
How to make Greek-style baked beans This week it was announced that McDonald’s has signed a deal with Canadian airline WestJet, to start offering McDonald’s onboard all WestJet flights.
Which sounds very exciting, but there is a caveat: for now, they’ll only be serving McDonald’s coffee.
So no Big Macs or fries at 35,000 feet, sadly. Yet.
But if you are a diehard fan of a nice McCafé, you’re in luck. From December 1, if you happen to be taking a WestJet flight, you’ll be treated to complimentary McDonald’s coffee.
Take your day from good to great with #McCafeonWestJet . Available across our entire Boeing jet fleet as of Dec 1, 2016 pic.twitter.com/jPQyq4zkeL 
— WestJet (@WestJet) November 24, 2016 

But this is not just any McDonald’s coffee. This fancy flight-friendly coffee.
To counteract the dulling of the senses caused by altitude and the plane’s cabin, the McDonald’s coffee that’ll be served on flights has been specially brewed with darker roasted beans and a slightly hotter water temperature (frequent fliers, please be careful not to burn your tongue).
McDonald’s beat out Starbucks and Canadian coffee brand Tim Hortons for the deal.
(Picture: Bruce Bennett/Getty Images) Now, to be clear, neither McDonald’s nor WestJet have announced any plans to expand this new offering and start selling burgers and McNuggets on flights. They’re likely just focusing on getting the coffee bit right for now.
But we’re hopeful that this union will open the (plane) doors to the possibility of a full McDonald’s menu being served above the clouds.
Yes, that is Mitt Romney handing out burgers on a flight. (Picture: JIM WATSON/AFP/GettyImages) Because damnit, we need to one day be able to eat a McDonald’s breakfast in the sky.*
*Without having to smuggle in hash browns while the person in the seat next to us delivers death stares.

thread.title: “Would you like human interaction with that?”: McDonald’s goes mobile
thread.title_full: “Would you like human interaction with that?”: McDonald’s goes mobile

posts.author: Kris Carlon
posts.title: “Would you like human interaction with that?”: McDonald’s goes mobile
posts.text:
TungCheung / Shutterstock.com 
Mobile ordering and payments are coming to McDonalds in 2017, meaning your interactions with pimple-faced teens will be dramatically reduced in the new year. Some McDonald’s restaurants have already begun installing self-serve kiosks and “smart” menu boards in the U.S., but table service and custom sandwiches are also on their way, Reuters reports.
Around 500 McDonald’s restaurants across the country have already got self-service kiosks, with other key markets making the changes in early 2017. Mobile ordering and payments will kick off in early 2017 as a pilot project and become the status quo in the second half of the year.
See also: Going to McDonalds right now might actually improve your fitness August 18, 2016 The changes come as McDonald’s tries to play catch-up with other fast food chains like Dominos and Starbucks who were early adopters of a mobile-first attitude. The company has already made sweeping changes to its ingredients to focus on a healthier contemporary image, including abandoning chickens raised with antibiotics and replacing margarine with butter and sugar with high-fructose corn syrup.
McDonald’s counter staff will reportedly not lose their jobs to ‘robots’ but will instead be redeployed to assist folks who have no idea how to operate the kiosks. Counter staff will also become servers to facilitate McDonald’s new focus on table service.
Ironically, McDonald’s USA chief executive, Steve Easterbrook, told Reuters “there is nothing more powerful than one-on-one customer experience” when explaining the addition of mobile ordering and payments to the McDonald’s app.
Are you happy to see McDonald’s modernizing? Or do you prefer real human interaction?

thread.title: McDonald’s strikes deal with WestJet airline to serve coffee at 35,000 feet
thread.title_full: McDonald’s strikes deal with WestJet airline to serve coffee at 35,000 feet

posts.author: Jessica Goodfellow
posts.title: McDonald’s strikes deal with WestJet airline to serve coffee at 35,000 feet
posts.text:
McDonald’s strikes deal with WestJet airline to serve coffee at 35,000 feet By Jessica Goodfellow - 26 November 2016 11:56am McDonald's coffee 
McDonald’s has beaten Starbucks and Canadian coffee brand Tim Hortons to a deal with WestJet airlines that will see the fast food company’s coffee served to customers at 35,000 feet for the first time. 
The deal with Canadian airline WestJet will mean McCafé’s Premium Roast will be offered as complimentary beverages on-board, first introduced last week on its Toronto to Calgary route. The roll-out to the rest of the airline will start on 1 December, when all passengers will be offered a McCafé as one of their complimentary drinks. 
The coffee has been specially brewed to adjust to higher altitudes which dull the senses, using a darker roast of beans used as well as a slightly hotter water temperature. Coffees which require steamed milk like cappuccino and lattes will not be available. 
John Betts, president of McDonald’s Canada, said: “We’ve always believed that the sky is the limit for McCafé - and today this officially rings true.” 
Take your day from good to great with #McCafeonWestJet . Available across our entire Boeing jet fleet as of Dec 1, 2016 pic.twitter.com/jPQyq4zkeL 
— WestJet (@WestJet) November 24, 2016 
WestJet’s chief executive Gregg Saretsky told the Toronto Star that the airline serves 30,000 cups of coffee a day. It is not yet known if McDonald’s food will be served on the airline in the future, but Saretsky did not rule it out in an interview with the Star: “Possibly. We really want to make sure we get the coffee right first.” 
McDonald’s has been pumping much of its marketing budget into propelling its coffee brand, diversifying beyond fast food. McCafé was the number four coffee brand in the UK when it signed Channel 4 last year to create real-time ads in between hit shows Gogglebox and The Island with Bear Grylls. 
The ads, ‘McCafé moments’ took cues from Gogglebox by putting regular people in a cafe set to discuss what just happened in the show. As a result of the ads, McCafé leapt to become the number two coffee brand in the UK, with 10 million cups of coffee sold during the campaign.

The remaining trees will be available from 1-3 p.m. on a first-come basis at the McDonald’s on Eight Mile Road near Woodward Avenue.
The trees are 5 feet tall to 6 feet tall.
Event organizers say Detroit-area McDonald’s restaurant owners also have donated turkeys, hats and scarfs, school supplies and other items to families in need as part of their support for the community.

Hollis Johnson 
The fast-food world exploded earlier this year at the revelation that McDonald's is testing a Chicken McGriddle sandwich.
Even better news: McDonald's has since  expanded  the test, rolling it out to several other regions across Ohio, which suggests that the sandwich has been a big hit in the state so far.  
The new item combines a fried chicken patty and the sweet pancake buns of the McGriddle breakfast sandwich.
Only time — and Ohioans — will tell if the sandwich has national staying power. But we couldn't wait to try it for ourselves, so we decided to construct our own Chicken McGriddle.
So how to go about constructing your own Chicken McGriddle? It's pretty simple. First, buy a simple Sausage McGriddle and a Crispy Buttermilk Chicken sandwich. Hollis Johnson 

The humble Sausage McGriddle works best, as there's no egg or cheese to mess with. Hollis Johnson 

After all, it's the buns we're after here. The McGriddle buns are specially formulated with maple-syrup crystals to give a sweet, syrupy flavor without the sticky mess. Hollis Johnson

posts.author: cbs8
posts.title: McDonald's introducing Grand Mac and Mac Jr.
posts.text:
(CNN) - McDonald's signature hamburger is getting company.
The fast food franchise is adding two new burgers inspired by the Big Mac to its line-up next year.
The Grand Mac is made with one-third pound of beef while the Mac Jr. is a single-layer burger.
You could say the Grand Mac is what you'd get if you up-sized the Big Mac and the Mac Jr. is what you would get if you shrunk it.
All three will still have all-beef patties, special sauce, lettuce,  cheese, pickles and onions on a Sesame seed bun.
The Grand Mac and the Mac Jr. will be sold for a limited time on McDonald's national menu in early 2017.
Copyright 2016 CNN.

thread.title: New book, movie about San Diego's Joan and Ray Kroc
thread.title_full: New book, movie about San Diego's Joan and Ray Kroc - The San Diego Union-Tribune

posts.author: John Wilkens
posts.title: New book, movie about San Diego's Joan and Ray Kroc
posts.text:
Ray and Joan Kroc are San Diego giants — he turned McDonald’s into a fast-food fortune, she gave it away to charity — and in the years since their deaths, they’ve become the stuff of admiring legend and lore.
A new biography returns them to the realm of the earthbound, much more complicated and conflicted than their saintly public personas.
Written by veteran newspaper and radio journalist Lisa Napoli, “Ray & Joan” is also an interesting look at the vagaries of chance, how the seemingly random crossing of paths can send someone’s life in another direction. There’s a reason Joan Kroc named both her airplane and her yacht “Impromptu.”
“They were larger-than-life characters,” Napoli said. “People either loved them, or they didn’t. There was a certain imperiousness about them. But Joan also sounds like someone who was so much fun. And so was Ray.”
Napoli spent five years researching and writing the book, working without cooperation from McDonald’s and its historical archives, and receiving what she described as limited and “reluctant” assistance from Kroc relatives. She relied on newspaper archives, court records and dozens of interviews, some of them with people identified only as “confidante” in the footnotes.
The book that emerged is several stories rolled into one. There’s the origin story of McDonald’s, the hamburger empire that Ray Kroc built using someone else’s idea. There’s his love story with Joan Kroc, a romance started after an unplanned meeting in an elegant Minnesota supper club, when both were married to others. And there’s the final fairy tale, the millions and millions and millions of dollars dropped into the unsuspecting laps of various organizations after Joan Kroc died and included them in her will.
Some of the book is set in San Diego, where the Krocs moved after he bought the Padres in 1974, when it looked as if the major league baseball team would be moved to Washington, D.C. That rescue endeared him forever to many San Diegans, and following his death a decade later — nine months before the team made its first appearance in the World Series — his wife left her own mark with a string of charitable donations that earned her the nickname “St. Joan of the Arches.”
Today the Kroc name adorns a number of buildings in town: a Salvation Army recreation center in Rolando, a peace institute at the University of San Diego, an animal shelter in Mission Valley, a residential center for the homeless in East Village.
“Joan was sharp, interested, involved, and very humble,” said Joyce Neu, founding director of the Joan B. Kroc Institute for Peace and Justice at USD. “Anyone who knew her felt very lucky.”
The book came out Nov. 15, almost exactly one month before a new movie, “The Founder,” opens in limited, Oscar-qualifying release before a wider distribution in January. It stars Michael Keaton as Ray and Linda Cardellini as Joan, and focuses on the early years of McDonald’s. A trailer for the movie has a brief shot of them sitting together at a piano, smiling.
They were having a moment. Then, and now.
What ifs The Brooklyn-born Napoli worked for The New York Times before moving to Southern California in 2004 and taking a job with the public radio show “Marketplace.” She said she’s long been drawn to “what if” moments in her reporting, and the Kroc story has plenty of them.
Lisa Napoli Preston Wiles Lisa Napoli Lisa Napoli (Preston Wiles) What if Ray Kroc hadn’t been a paper-cup salesman, which led him to a milkshake maker, which led him to a roadside hamburger stand in San Bernardino called McDonald’s?
What if he hadn’t walked into a candlelit St. Paul, Minn., supper club for a meeting with a potential McDonald’s franchisee and been smitten by the organ player — Joan — who was 26 years his junior?
What if Joan hadn’t decided she’d reject the traditional charity-giving route of using a foundation to distribute money, and instead gave it away based on her own eclectic, emotional connection to various issues (alcoholism, nuclear proliferation, animal welfare, public radio, the Salvation Army, hospice)?
“Fate, chance — whatever you want to call it, it’s a powerful force,” Napoli said.
It played a role in her doing the book, too.
Almost five years ago, Napoli was exploring a story about a 26-foot-tall sculpture in Santa Monica of a mushroom cloud constructed out of twisted chains. Conceived by the late political cartoonist Paul Conrad, who saw it as a peace statement, the sculpture had fallen into disrepair. Its fate was uncertain.
Visiting the site, Napoli met a peace activist who whispered in her ear that the cost of the artwork had been underwritten anonymously two decades earlier by Joan Kroc. Napoli knew Kroc lived in San Diego and had given a bunch of money to National Public Radio when she died, but she wanted to know more. She went looking for a biography about the philanthropist.
“There wasn’t one,” Napoli writes in the acknowledgments of her book, “so I appointed myself the woman for the job.”
She appointed herself even though she’d never written a biography before, and even though the scope of the project soon changed. Napoli thought she was going to do a book about Joan Kroc. “But I realized I couldn’t tell the story of Joan without the story of Ray,” she said.
The story of Ray she wrote includes details about his relentless ambition and his fondness for Early Times whiskey. About how even as he understood that post-war America would embrace fast food, he clashed with his partners about the best approach. About how he felt so close to Joan after they married that he named his boat JoniRay, no space, but his temper was so volatile she briefly filed for divorce.
Napoli said as she dug into the history of Kroc and McDonald’s, the company “was not helpful at all.” (The firm did not respond to a Union-Tribune request for comment.) She also had difficulties when it came to Joan Kroc, who didn’t keep copies of her correspondence and other papers.
That may be because Kroc never wanted a book written about her, something that gave the author pause. “I struggled with that a lot,” Napoli said.
Carving her own path People who only know of Joan Kroc from her San Diego years sometimes think she was always wealthy and glamorous. They don’t know about the struggles Napoli covers in her book. How Joan Kroc and her first husband used a $50 prize their 5-year-old daughter won in a talent contest to pay the rent. How when they first arrived in Rapid City, S.D., to open a McDonald’s, Joan had to her name exactly $1.65. Her husband did well with the restaurant, but she took to calling their hometown “Wretched City.”
She and Ray Kroc divorced their spouses and got married in 1969, and she settled uneasily into a life of luxury — private airplanes, 42-carat diamond necklaces, Renoirs and Rockwells — where making a living or finding a purpose wasn’t required. “Joan didn’t want an occupation or a project foisted on her by Ray or anyone in his circle,” Napoli wrote. “She was searching to carve her own path.”
That would come through philanthropy. For Napoli, the episode that speaks most directly to Kroc’s generosity happened in 1984, when a gunman opened fire at the McDonald’s in San Ysidro, killing 21 people and injuring 19 others before he was fatally shot by a police sniper. Kroc donated $100,000 to a fund for the victims’ families, and insisted the gunman’s widow and two children be among the recipients.
“At that terrible time, she wasn’t thinking about McDonald’s,” Napoli said. “ She was thinking about the victims.”
Over and over, Kroc was moved to action by something she read in the newspapers or saw on television. She gave money to USD and Notre Dame, both Catholic colleges, even though she wasn’t Catholic. Many of the causes were things that her late husband, who was politically conservative, wouldn’t have supported. She often insisted on anonymity when she made a donation.
“She was a very down-to-Earth person, totally unpretentious and at ease with people,” Neu, the former USD administrator said. She remembered meeting Kroc for the first time at breakfast. Neu’s meal came with hash browns. Kroc leaned over with her fork and asked, “Are you going to eat those, dear?”
In the summer of 2003, Joan Kroc celebrated her 75th birthday with a party at her Fairbanks Ranch estate. She was dying from brain cancer and she knew it. She invited officials from organizations that had received major donations from her in the past and would again after she died.
“We are going to do great things together,” she told them.
But some of them didn’t know what exactly was coming. The head of NPR would have been happy with $25,000. NPR got $225 million. The Salvation Army received $1.5 billion.
“The idea that you could make that kind of surprise for someone must have been such a thrill for her,” Napoli said. “She was giving them not just gifts, but gifts that would be transformational. How amazing is that?”
Lisa Napoli will be at the La Jolla Riford Library on Dec. 3 at 2 p.m. to discuss and sign “Ray & Joan.” Details: warwicks.com or (858) 454-0347.

posts.author: detroitnews.com
posts.title: Donated trees spread holiday spirit for Detroiters
posts.text:
Buy Photo Phillip Felnder, a McDonald's employee in Detroit, helps carry trees during Saturday’s tree giveaway, hosted by the McDonald’s on Eight Mile at Woodward. (Photo: Virginia Lozano / The Detroit News) Buy Photo 
Facebook Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Christmas tree giveaway at Detroit McDonald’s   Fullscreen Post to Facebook Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 
Buy Photo To brighten the holidays for Detroiters, Detroit-areea McDonald's owners gave away 1,000 trees on Saturday, November 26, 2016.  Virginia Lozano, The Detroit News Fullscreen Buy Photo Savarior Moss-Service, owner of the McDonald's on Eight Mile at Woodward, oversees the tree giveaway operation.  Virginia Lozano, The Detroit News Fullscreen Danielle Garner of Detroit ties a tree to the top of her car Saturday, November 26, 2016, during a holiday tree giveaway at McDonald's on Eight Mile at Woodward.  Virginia Lozano, Michigan Photography Fullscreen Buy Photo Joe Srebernak of Grosse Pointe carries a pair of trees out of a truck for the giveaway hosted by McDonald's on Eight Mile. The truck carried 75 trees that did not fit into the first truck, for a total of 1,000 trees that were given away Saturday, November 26, 2016.  Virginia Lozano, The Detroit News Fullscreen Buy Photo Kelly King of Detroit and her son De-Andre, 14, celebrate her birthday by getting a tree.  Virginia Lozano, The Detroit News Fullscreen Buy Photo After receiving a free Christmas tree, a car waits in the McDonald's drive-through.  Virginia Lozano, The Detroit News Fullscreen Buy Photo Edith Peters, a McDonald's employee for 40 years, and Maureen Smith, a McDonald's employee for 38 years and vice president of operations, spend time at the tree giveaway hosted by the McDonald's on Eight Mile.  Virginia Lozano, The Detroit News Fullscreen Buy Photo Anthony Carrier, left, ties a tree to the top of a car while volunteering for McDonald's during a tree giveaway Saturday, November 16, 2016..  Virginia Lozano, The Detroit News Fullscreen Buy Photo Phillip Felnder, a Detroit McDonald's employee, helps carry trees for the giveaway and for fellow employees.  Virginia Lozano, The Detroit News Fullscreen Buy Photo Anthony Reese Jr., 8, of Detroit gets into his father's car with an ice cream cone after receiving their tree from McDonald's.  Virginia Lozano, The Detroit News Fullscreen Buy Photo Norman and Terri Satchel of Detroit load a tree into the back of their car for Terri's 73-year-old mother, who could not make it out to the giveaway.  Virginia Lozano, The Detroit News Fullscreen Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay 1 of 11 2 of 11 3 of 11 4 of 11 5 of 11 6 of 11 7 of 11 8 of 11 9 of 11 10 of 11 11 of 11 Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide It was like Christmas came early for Tanya Edwards in the brisk chill on Saturday afternoon.
The 40-year-old Detroiter and her nephew Lamon Johnson, 12, loaded the back of her truck with two Christmas trees — free as part of a giveaway to the public and sponsored by McDonald’s — in the parking lot outside the fast food restaurant on Eight Mile at Woodward Avenue.
“I feel pretty good about it. I’ve never even had a real tree before so I’m kinda excited,” said Edwards, who minutes later went back and got another tree for another relative. “I’ve always had the artificial trees. Actually my cousin had come up here and said that they were giving out trees and to pass the word along.”
And the word spread fast as 500 trees were given away to families starting at 1 p.m. on a first-come, first-served basis. One tree was provided to each person who showed up, and in some cases, people came jammed in cars as volunteers helped to secure multiple trees on tops of vehicles.
Organizers said that prior to the public giveaway, another 500 trees were given in the morning to families in need and preselected by Detroit-area churches. Meijer provided 500 tree stands to those families, as well as $20 Meijer and $5 McDonald’s gift cards.
Some people waited in line to have trees strapped on to their cars or loaded into trucks; others simply walked up and carried the trees ranging from 5 to 7 feet tall to their vehicles.
Savarior Moss-Service, owner of the McDonald’s near Eight Mile and Woodward, said the Christmas tree giveaway was another way to give back to the community, as were the 1,200 turkeys given away on Tuesday for Thanksgiving.
“We decided that it would be good to take it one step further, so we came up with the idea with our public relations company and said, how about Christmas trees,” Moss-Service said. “We always like to set aside our advertising dollars and budget to actually do things in the community. Usually we’re giving away scarfs, hats, mittens around this time of the year but this time we said Christmas trees. It makes the house more festive.”
Elizabeth Riachi, 54, of southwest Detroit, had some friends help her fetch at least four trees and place them on the roof of the SUV she was being driven in, a few of them for neighbors who couldn’t make it.
“We’re donating them to the seniors in the neighborhood,” Riachi said. “They couldn’t get out here. Some of them are not walking but we want to share their Christmas.”
Yamirka Torres, 24, who rode with Riachi, said she usually buys real trees every year at Home Depot for $25 to $30 but changed her mind when she found out about the giveaway.
“A lot of people decided to come together,” Torres said. “It saves gas.”
Most importantly, Riachi said these trees will “bring a little cheer” to people’s lives, especially those who don’t have access to a Christmas tree.
“If we come into their home and put up the tree, that will be a blessing,” she said.

thread.title: McDonald’s sues Florence after city mayor bans chain from opening branch in historic Piazza del Duomo
thread.title_full: McDonald’s sues Florence after city mayor bans chain from opening branch in historic Piazza del Duomo

posts.author: David Millward
posts.title: McDonald’s sues Florence after city mayor bans chain from opening branch in historic Piazza del Duomo
posts.text:
McDonald’s sues Florence after city mayor bans chain from opening branch in historic Piazza del Duomo Sunset view of Ponte Vecchio, Florence, Credit: Luciano Mortula David Millward 27 November 2016 • 3:38am 
Dario Nardella, the city’s centre left mayor, rejected he application in June, a decision which was upheld by the technical panel responsible for preserving Florence’s character. 
However, the Local reported , McDonald’s has lodged a claim with the administrative court. 
The chain has more than 35,000 branches across the world, including three in Florence itself. But placing an outlet in the iconic heart of the city was a step too far. McDonald's restaurant sign Credit: Greg Balfour Evans/Alamy 
"McDonald's has the right to submit an application, because this is permitted under the law, but we also have the right to say no," Mr Nardella told the city council, saying he wanted to support "traditional business" in the area. 
"We don't have any prejudice" against McDonald's, Mr Nardella said, noting that the company had opened restaurants "in other parts of town. 
T he plans to open a branch in the Piazza triggered a Facebook campaign supporting moves to block a branch being opened in a Unesco World Heritage site. 
McDonald’s is seeking $19.65 million (£15.75 million) in damages. 
The company said, in a statement: "We completely agree that the cultural and artistic heritage and the Italian historical town centres have to be protected and guaranteed, as well as the traditions and the historical small shops, but we cannot accept discriminatory regulations that damage the freedom of private initiative without being advantageous to anyone Follow Telegraph News

thread.title: McDonald's USA Planning Big Tech Push For Next Year, Finally Adding Mobile Orders In 2017
thread.title_full: McDonald's USA Planning Big Tech Push For Next Year, Finally Adding Mobile Orders In 2017

posts.title: McDonald's USA Planning Big Tech Push For Next Year, Finally Adding Mobile Orders In 2017
posts.text:
McDonald's USA Planning Big Tech Push For Next Year, Finally Adding Mobile Orders In 2017 27 November 2016, 6:05 am EST By Alexandra Burlacu Tech Times McDonald's USA is finally planning to join the mobile era, introducing mobile ordering next year. Moreover, the fast-food chain also wants to deploy self-serving kiosks to make ordering quicker and easier. ( Justin Sullivan | Getty Images ) Advertisement 
Ordering a Big Mac from MacDonald's should become a lot easier next year, as the fast-food chain reportedly plans to introduce mobile ordering next year. 
Fast food has the obvious advantage of being ready, but big lines and McDonald's registers or drive-thru can take a whole lot longer. This should be a thing of the past come next year, however, as McDonald's USA is planning a big tech push and is finally joining the mobile era in 2017. 
Although it's one of the world's most popular fast-food chains, McDonald's has been rather slow in adopting new technology. While other popular chains such as Starbucks , Papa John's , Pizza Hut , Domino's and others have embraced apps to facilitate ordering, McDonald's has remained one step behind in this department. McDonald's Mobile Ordering 
According to a recent Reuter's report , that's about to change. Starting in the first half of next year, McDonald's will reportedly allow customers to order items off its menu through the McDonald's smartphone app. Customers will be able to pay for the order within the app as well, so ordering McDonald's food will get a lot easier and faster. 
McDonald's has yet to provide specific details on its mobile ordering rollout, but Reuters notes that a pilot will take place in the first half of 2017, with a full national rollout set for the second half of the year. The information comes from Chris Kempczinski, a former Kraft Foods exec who will be the president of McDonald's USA come Jan. 1, 2017. Kempzinski reportedly talked about McDonald's plans for next year at an event in New York City. 
"As the company tries to become a 'modern, progressive company,' as one of its executive noted on Thursday, this is just the latest step to attract customers," TechnoBuffalo points out . 
The McDonald's app has already racked up an impressive 16 million downloads, and the ability to order and pay for food and beverages within the app will surely make it even more popular. McDonald's Self-Serving Kiosks 
The fast-food chain reportedly wants to make hefty investments in self-serving kiosks as well and is willing to help franchises deploy such kiosks by contributing money or financing. Deploying self-serving kiosks is expected to cost between $50,000 and $60,000, said McDonald's CEO Steve Easterbrook. The CEO further added that installing such kiosks is not expected to reduce the number of employees working in restaurants, as they would still have to help customers learn how to order through kiosks and the deliver the orders to customers' tables.

thread.title: Saffold, Kendricks and McDonald must deliver for Rams
thread.title_full: Saffold, Kendricks and McDonald must deliver for Rams

posts.title: Saffold, Kendricks and McDonald must deliver for Rams
posts.text:
Saffold, Kendricks and McDonald must deliver for Rams Rodger Saffold Robert Gauthier/Los Angeles Times Rams guard Rodger Saffold gets ready to take the field before a game earlier this season. Rams guard Rodger Saffold gets ready to take the field before a game earlier this season. (Robert Gauthier/Los Angeles Times) 
RAMS WHO MUST DELIVER ... 
Offensive lineman Rodger Saffold . The versatile veteran, who in his career has played every position on the line except center, has started 10 games at left guard next to struggling tackle Greg Robinson. The Rams need Saffold to step up and lead a unit that must protect rookie quarterback Jared Goff and pave the way for back Todd Gurley . 
Tight end Lance Kendricks . He committed a costly penalty late in last week’s loss to Miami, two weeks after dropping a certain touchdown pass at the Coliseum against Carolina. Kendricks did, however, catch four passes against the Dolphins , and the Rams need him to be a reliable veteran presence for rookie Goff. 
Safety T.J. McDonald. The Rams intercepted one pass against the Dolphins but they could have had several more, including one that was knocked out of McDonald’s grasp. McDonald helped set the aggressive tone against Miami and needs to do the same against Saints receivers who are deployed all over the field. 
SAINTS TO WATCH OUT FOR ... 
Tight end Coby Fleener . Receivers Brandin Cooks, Michael Thomas and Willie Snead get most of the attention, but Fleener also has been productive for quarterback Drew Brees . Fleener has 33 catches for 402 yards and has scored three touchdowns. 
Running back Mark Ingram . With 16th-year quarterback Drew Brees directing the NFL’s top passing offense, it’s easy to forget about Ingram, who was going through concussion protocol last week but has said he expects to play. The 2009 Heisman Trophy winner from Alabama is averaging 4.7 yards a carry and has rushed for two touchdowns. 
Defensive end Cameron Jordan . The former California star has four sacks and has forced a fumble for a defense that has not played poorly as of late (ranked 14th against the rush, and 27th overall). The 6-foot-4, 287-pound Jordan, the 24th player chosen in the 2011 draft, would no doubt like to make it uncomfortable for Rams rookie quarterback Jared Goff, the No. 1 pick in the draft from Cal.

thread.title: Couple accused of having sex in McDonald’s parking lot as 6-year-old watched | WPMT FOX43
thread.title_full: Couple accused of having sex in McDonald’s parking lot as 6-year-old watched | WPMT FOX43

posts.author: Tribune Media Wire
posts.title: Couple accused of having sex in McDonald’s parking lot as 6-year-old watched | WPMT FOX43
posts.text:
Email 
ORANGE, Conn. – Two McDonald’s employees called police after walking out of the restaurant to find a couple in a parked car “engaged in sexual activity,” police said Monday. 
The workers had just finished their shifts at the Orange, Connecticut, McDonald’s around 9:30 p.m. on November 15, when they noticed the vehicle. One of the employees told a 911 operator it appeared the pair were having sex, and that “a small child was seated in the back, watching,” according to police. Kimberly Onorato, 28, and Rory Clark, 27, allegedly told police that they were “cuddling” after two McDonald’s employees called 911 to report two people engaged in sexual activity in the parking lot. (Town of Orange Police Department) 
When police arrived, they found a woman partially-naked in the front seat with a man, and a 6-year-old in the back seat who was “alert and awake,” WTIC reported. 
The couple said they were “cuddling” after eating at McDonald’s, according to police. 
Officers arrested Rory Clark, 27, of West Haven, and Kimberly Onorato, 28, of Bristol. Both were charged with second-degree breach of peace and impairing the morals of a minor. 
They were both released on $5,000 bond.

thread.title: Arkansas Man Wins Lawsuit. Was Fired From McDonald's For Being HIV+
thread.title_full: Arkansas Man Wins Lawsuit. Was Fired From McDonald's For Being HIV+

posts.author: Adam Dupuis
posts.title: Arkansas Man Wins Lawsuit. Was Fired From McDonald's For Being HIV+
posts.text:
26, 2016 

Discriminatory practices lost another case this month. 

A McDonald’s restaurant owned and operated by Mathews Management Co. and Peach Orchard Inc. in Bentonville, Ark., will pay $103,000 and furnish other relief to settle a disability discrimination lawsuit brought by the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC), the agency announced. 
EEOC’s lawsuit challenged McDonald’s treatment of an employee when the restaurant fired him within days of learning of his HIV-positive status. The suit also charged that the companies’ policy of requiring all employees to report the use of prescription medication is also unlawful. 
Such alleged conduct violates the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). EEOC filed suit ( Mathews Management and Peach Orchard, Inc. d/b/a McDonald’s Store # 32295 , Civil Action No. 5:16-CV-05166TLB) in U.S. District Court for the Western District of Arkansas, Fayetteville Division, after first attempting to reach a voluntary pre-litigation settlement through its conciliation process. 
After EEOC filed suit, the former employee intervened in the case with his own lawsuit and was represented by Joshua L. Bailey of the Hogue Law Firm in Fayetteville, Ark. 
In addition to the monetary payment, the companies will also conduct disability training for its managers and revise their policy requiring mandatory disclosure of prescription medications. 
Mathews Management Company owns and operates 34 McDonald’s restaurants, including all of the restaurants in Northwest Arkansas and adjacent areas in Missouri and Oklahoma. This includes the store located in Bentonville. - insurancejournal.com 


It was not stated if John Doe (as he was referred to in the lawsuit) was LGBT. If he was fired for being LGBT, there would have been no protection for him. As we reported in February of 2015, just around the time when Doe was fired, It's Official: Non-Discrimination Laws Protecting LGBT Are Now Illegal In Arkansas: 

Republican Gov. Asa Hutchinson allowed legislation to go into law without his signature that bars cities and counties from expanding anti-discrimination ordinances beyond what the state already prohibits, making Arkansas the second state to approve such a prohibition. Arkansas' anti-discrimination protections don't include sexual orientation or gender identity. Monday marked the end of the five-day window for Hutchinson to take action on the bill or allow it to become law. 
Hutchinson had raised concerns about the bill infringing on local control, but said he wouldn't veto it. His office said his position hadn't changed and he allowed the proposal to become law, despite a last-ditch campaign by advocacy groups urging him to veto the legislation. The law won't take effect until 90 days after the Legislature formally adjourns, which is currently set for May. - The Associated Press 

Congrats Mr. Doe for your win.

posts.title: McDonald's introducing Grand Mac and Mac Jr. - MSNewsNow.com - Jackson, MS
posts.text:
McDonald's introducing Grand Mac and Mac Jr. 2016-11-25T22:44:37Z McDonald's restaurant is adding new burgers to its menu. (Source: CNN) 
(CNN) - McDonald's signature hamburger is getting company. 
The fast food franchise is adding two new burgers inspired by the Big Mac to its line-up next year. 
The Grand Mac is made with one-third pound of beef while the Mac Jr. is a single-layer burger. 
You could say the Grand Mac is what you'd get if you up-sized the Big Mac and the Mac Jr. is what you would get if you shrunk it. 
All three will still have all-beef patties, special sauce, lettuce, cheese, pickles and onions on a Sesame seed bun. 
The Grand Mac and the Mac Jr. will be sold for a limited time on McDonald's national menu in early 2017.

thread.title: Vehicle crashes into Decor Furniture, McDonald's sign
thread.title_full: Vehicle crashes into Decor Furniture, McDonald's sign

posts.author: Kaitlin L Lange, IndyStar
posts.title: Vehicle crashes into Decor Furniture, McDonald's sign
posts.text:
Vehicle crashes into Decor Furniture, McDonald's sign Kaitlin L Lange , IndyStar 2:48   The driver is being investigated for a possible OWI and endangerment of a child. A 35-year-old man drove his vehicle into the corner of Decor Furniture, before hitting a McDonald's sign. (Photo: Photo provided by Indianapolis Fire Department) 
A vehicle drove into the corner of Decor Furniture before hitting a McDonald's sign poll on the east side of Indianapolis Sunday morning. 
A 35-year-old man was seen driving a Gold Ford E150 van erratically, heading east on 10th Street, around 11:40 a.m. Sunday. About a minute later, he crashed into the store located at E. 10th St. and N. Bosart Ave., according to a release from the Indianapolis Fire Department. After the vehicle drove through the corner of the building, the van crossed Bosart Avenue and hit a McDonald's poll. 
After coming to a stop, the five individuals in the car fled the scene. The driver of the car grabbed a six-year-old boy who had been in the car, before fleeing. 
IMPD found the driver, and he is being investigated for suspicion of OWI and possible endangerment of a child, according to the release. 
There were no injuries. 
The building was stabilized by IFD's Collapse Rescue Team, but they expect damage to the store to cost $35,000 to fix. 
Follow IndyStar reporter Kaitlin Lange on Twitter: @kaitlin_lange.  //indy.st/2gw4g6Y TOP VIDEOS

thread.title: The real story behind McDonald’s mysterious 'Gold Card' — the ticket to unlimited free fast food
thread.title_full: The real story behind McDonald’s mysterious 'Gold Card' — the ticket to unlimited free fast food

posts.author: Kate Taylor
posts.title: The real story behind McDonald’s mysterious 'Gold Card' — the ticket to unlimited free fast food
posts.text:
The real story behind McDonald’s mysterious 'Gold Card' — the ticket to unlimited free fast food Business Insider 1 hr ago Kate Taylor © By arugatse on Flickr When Rob Lowe appeared on Jimmy Kimmel Live with a golden McDonald’s card last year, one big question remained: How could the Average Joe get his own card that granted him access to unlimited McDonald's?
Quote: s in the article McDonald's Corp MCD
▲ 120.66 +0.52 +0.43% Not easily, a little sleuthing revealed.
The first complication: Rob Lowe's Gold Card was not issued by McDonald’s corporate office. Instead, it is from the owner of, and can only be used at, McDonald’s franchises in Santa Barbara or Goleta, California.
While Lowe says he received the Gold Card because his buddy’s dad created the McMuffin, McDonald's confirmed to Business Insider that he in fact received the card from David Peterson — the buddy in question, who is now a McDonald’s franchisee himself.
© AP Images Herb Peterson, who passed away in 2008, was a legendary force in the fast-food world. He debuted the first Egg McMuffin at the Santa Barbara McDonald's he co-owned with David in 1972 . Peterson started his work with McDonald’s as the vice president of the company’s advertising firm, D’Arcy Advertising, and went on to become a franchisee and operator of six McDonald’s locations.
Today, David Peterson has carried on his father’s legacy with the chain. Earlier this year, the franchises he runs in the Santa Barbara and Goleta areas became some of the first to launch “taste-crafted” sandwiches as part of the McDonald’s turnaround plan, reports local news station KEYT.
Peterson also wields the power to give out Gold Cards, granting the recipient free McDonald’s at the locations he owns and operates. While Lowe is quite likely the most high-profile person to be awarded the card, he is not the first — just the first to brag about it on late-night TV.
For example, Larry Crandell was awarded a Gold Card by Peterson on his 90th birthday, reports SantaBarbara.com. While the cards are nearly identical, unlike Lowe’s card, Crandell’s awarded him free McDonald’s for life.
Crandell is a bit of a celebrity in Santa Barbara, having reportedly helped raise millions of dollars for the community as a volunteer and expert emcee.
Assuming you aren't a famous actor who has a personal connection with David Peterson or a local legend in Santa Barbara, California, there are other ways to get free McDonald’s.
In fact, McDonald's franchisees across the country appear to be more than happy to give local heroes free food with their own versions of the “Gold Card.”
© Provided by Business Insider Warren Buffett Warren Buffett told CNBC he had a McDonald’s card that allowed him to order unlimited food for free in Omaha.
Charles Ramsey , who ditched his half-eaten Big Mac to help rescue three kidnapped women in May 2013, was awarded free McDonald’s at all locations for a year and unlimited McDonald's for the rest of his life at local Ohio restaurants.
In March, Ottawa Senators goalie Andrew Hammond, nicknamed the Hamburglar, received a card that gave him free McDonald’s for life from an Ottawa franchisee who, coincidentally, was also the father of Hammond's former coach.
However, there are only two major confirmed stories of people in possession of cards granting them free, unlimited McDonald's anywhere in the country, or even the world.
While on the campaign trail in 2012, Mitt Romney told a story of how his father had a " little pink card " that awarded him free McDonald’s for life. McDonald’s confirmed that founder Ray Kroc had given Romney the card, but did not have any record of the reason for the gift. However, the chain noted that Kroc was known to informally gift these Lifetime "Be Our Guest" cards to various people throughout the years.
© Provided by Business Insider Bill Gates The other lucky recipient of a lifetime of free McDonald's — not a little pink card, but a bona fide Gold Card, according to the company — is Bill Gates. According to Warren Buffett, Gates' card works worldwide. Of course, it is unclear how often Gates stops by McDonald’s these days, after The Gates Foundation Asset Trust liquidated its position in the fast-food company in February 2015.
Getting your hands on a McDonald's Gold Card is no piece of cake. But, the legendary cards are real — and something that could end up in your own pocket, if you befriend the right McDonald’s franchisee.

thread.title: Falun Gong Practitioners Participate in Chicago Thanksgiving Parade | Opinion
thread.title_full: Falun Gong Practitioners Participate in Chicago Thanksgiving Parade | Opinion

posts.author: beforeitsnews.com
posts.title: Falun Gong Practitioners Participate in Chicago Thanksgiving Parade | Opinion
posts.text:
(Before It's News)
(Minghui.org) The 83rd McDonald’s® Thanksgiving Parade was held in Chicago on November 24, 2016. Falun Gong (also known as Falun Dafa) practitioners were invited to participate in the parade. They have participated in the annual parade for over ten consecutive years. The Falun Gong procession was placed in the tenth position of the parade. Their rich cultural performance earned warm applause from spectators.
The Thanksgiving parade is the biggest parade in Chicago. It is estimated that 400,000 viewers watch the parade in person, and 3.5 million watch the live broadcast on TV each year. The hosting organization selected about 100 groups from numerous applicants. The magnificent parade features gigantic balloons, marching bands, cavalry, decorated floats, and colorful performing groups.
Falun Dafa practitioners participate in the 83rd Thanksgiving Parade in Chicago on November 24, 2016.
Celestial maidens perform in the parade.
Practitioners demonstrate the exercises on the float.
Lucy Atkinson from Cincinnati, Ohio, viewed the parade in person. She said that the Falun Gong procession was inspiring and that the float and dancing significantly enriched the parade. She was impressed most by the three words “Truthfulness-Compassion-Forbearance” displayed in the procession. She indicated that the words appeared peaceful and unifying.
In the audience were many Chinese viewers, including immigrant professionals, students, visitors, and tourists, who enjoyed watching the parade and experienced the freedom of seeing Falun Gong proudly displayed in the parade.
Mr. Cao, who came to the United States less than three years ago, works in suburban Chicago. He said, “I saw the Thanksgiving parade last year for the first time. I was so impressed, I came again this year.”
Watching the Falun Gong procession passing by, he added, “They are kind-hearted people. The procession is graceful and rich in Chinese traditional culture.
“I had misunderstandings about Falun Gong when I was in China. I have changed my view now, because it (Falun Gong) was banned in China and here it is quite different.”

posts.author: Breaking News Staff
posts.title: McDonald's owner IDs burglary suspect from security video
posts.text:
DAYTON A man was arrested shortly after a break-in at the McDonald’s restaurant, 1219 N. Gettysburg Ave.
Daniel D. Combs, 25, was arrested on suspicion of breaking and entering moments after the restaurant was burglarized early Friday morning, according to the Dayton police report.
Police said Combs was walking in the area when a responding officer detained him.
The restaurant owner, who saw the intruders on security video from his home, was able to positively identify Combs as one of the intruders, according to the report.
Additionally, police said a footprint on the drive’through window matched the shoes that Combs was wearing.
Several items were taken in the burglary, including a laptop, iPad, clothing and two pairs of Nike shoes, according to the report.
